stems.text: The following table summarises the minimum rate (per hour) that students must pay to be tutored by poly students, undergraduates, full-time tutors/ graduates and schoolteachers from a tutoring company.  The tutors from this company receive 80% of the rate payed by the student.

questions.text: If a poly student tutors a class of 3 upper primary students for 2 hours, what is the least amount of money that s/he will earn?

Suppose that a graduate offers one-on-one tutoring only and tutored a lower primary student for 1 hour, a lower secondary student for 2 hours and an upper secondary student for one hour (each for the minimum rate) on a particular day. What average rate (per hour) were the students charged that day?

Jim (an undergraduate tutor) is saving up for a $5000 car. He tutors a class of 3 lower secondary students for 2 hours every day. Given that all the money he earns from tutoring these students is saved for buying a car, what is the maximum number of days that Jim will take to save up the $5000 for the car?

A percentage increase of X% in the minimum rate that the tutoring company charges for lower secondary students occurs. As a result of this, it will take Jim 10 fewer days to save up the $5000 for his car. Which of the following is closest to the value of X?

stems.text: The following table illustrates the exchange rate of the USD.

questions.text: Emily wishes to buy a bike worth 450 Australian dollars, what is the value of the bike in US dollars?
Which of the following is closest to the conversion rate of Euros to British pounds?

Suppose that the value of the US dollar increases by 6% but the values of all other currencies remains unchanged. What is the percentage decrease/ increase in the number of American dollars per Japanese Yen?
questions.explanation: Simply a 6% increase as the US dollar increases by 6%

questions.text: An American family decides to move to Canada. The family has allocated 500,000 US dollars for the move and the house. They buy the house for 393,000 Canadian dollars but must pay an extra 6% on stamp duty. The other affiliated costs of making the move amounted to 48,000 US dollars. What percentage of the money allocated for the move and the house remained unspent?

stems.text: Joanne decided to partake in a 35km marathon, which she completed in exactly 7 hours. She went into the marathon with a specific strategy in mind. The following table depicts the cumulative distance (in km) covered by Joanne each hour since the marathon started.

questions.text: Suppose that Joanne stopped for a 15-minute toilet break half an hour into the marathon, what was Joanne’s average running speed for the course of the marathon?
Which of the following best describes Joanne’s marathon strategy?
options: Increasing speed followed by a plateau
questions.explanation: The difference between the cumulative distance each hour is higher at the later times when compared to the earlier

questions.text: If Joanne travelled X km/h faster (on average) in the first hour (but her speeds for the other hours of the marathon remained constant), Joanne could have finished the marathon in ~85.7% of the time. What is the value of X?
questions.explanation: 7 * 0.857 = 6; distance travelled in the last hour = 35 – 27 = 8km

questions.text: The first placed participant completed the marathon with an average speed of 10km/ hour. Given that Joanne maintained a constant speed each hour of the marathon (and altered her running speed at the end of each hour), roughly how far away was Joanne from the finish line when the first placed participant crossed the finish line?

stems.text: An experiment was conducted in a chemistry class to determine the effect of temperature on the rate of oxygen gas production (in a chemical reaction). The rate was measured in ml/s. The figure below illustrates the data obtained.

questions.text: What was the average increase in the rate of oxygen gas production per degrees Celsius for temperatures between 30 and 60 degrees Celsius (in ml/s)?
The chemical reaction occurred for 1 minute and 20 seconds at 46 degrees Celsius. What volume of oxygen gas was produced in that time as a result of the chemical reaction?
If 6 ml of oxygen gas was collected at 57 degrees Celsius in the experiment, how long did the chemical reaction occur for at 57 degrees Celsius (in minutes)?

When reviewing the experiment, it was found that the gas collection apparatus was in fact faulty and the volume of oxygen gas produced was 23% higher than the recorded value at each temperature. Suppose that, in order to calculate the true rate of oxygen gas production, a student does not alter the volume of oxygen gas in her calculations; however, instead, decreases the time value by X%. What is the value of X?

stems.text: The following table illustrates the distance (in miles) between various European cities. Planes regularly fly between these cities and travel in a straight, direct path to the destination.

questions.text: If an individual travels by plane from Warsaw to Moscow to Copenhagen to London and back to Warsaw, what is the fewest number of miles s/he will travel?
If the plane flies at an average of speed of 700 miles per hour, how long will it take to travel return from Rome to Moscow without stopping?
1 mile = 1.6km. If the plane flies at an average of speed of 900 km per hour and it takes 77.87 minutes to travel from city X to city Y, what do cities X and Y refer to?

The time difference between London and Moscow is 3 hours and Moscow is ahead of London. If the plane travels at 606 miles per hour and leaves from Moscow at 3PM (local time), what time will it arrive at London (local time)?

stems.text: The concentration of 2 different molecules in the bloodstream (Cisplatin and Cl-) after Cisplatin was administered to a patient is shown in the graph below. If chloride ions exceed 0.006M it may be toxic for the patient.

questions.text: What was the average rate of increase in Cl- concentration for the 10 hours since Cisplatin was administered?
Approximately how long did it take for the concentration of Cl- to increase to 3 times that of Cisplatin?
Concentration refers to the number of moles of a substance per litre of fluid (i.e/ blood). How many moles of Cl- were present in 5L of the patient’s blood after 6 hours?
questions.explanation: Slightly over 4; 4 * 10^-3 * 5 = 0.02; Therefore, slightly higher than 0.02

questions.text: What is the highest average rate of reduction (per minute) in the concentration of Cl- ions after 20 hours since Cisplatin was administered such that the concentration of Cl- ions drops below Cisplatin levels within one hour (in M per minute)?

stems.text: The following table compares the fuel efficiency and weights of a variety of different models of car.

questions.text: What is the average fuel efficiency of the models of car listed?
questions.explanation: Add the values in the 3rd column and divide by the number of car models

questions.text: Which of the car models has the greatest weight to fuel efficiency ratios – i.e/ if the weight to fuel efficiency ratio was expressed as X:1, for which car model would x be the largest?
questions.explanation: Expedition has the highest weight and the lowest fuel efficiency

questions.text: How much less fuel would be used by the civic than the explorer model of car if both travel 165km?
1 mile = 1.6 km. If an individual drives a ranger model of car at an average speed of 25 miles per hour for 512 minutes, how much fuel will it use (to the nearest litre)?

stems.text: The following table compares the rates (per mile) associated with the mileage fare of a taxi. In addition to the mileage fare, all taxis charge a fixed $5 flagging fare for each ride. The calculation of the mileage fare of a 40-mile taxi journey is provided below as an example.

questions.text: What would an individual have to pay for a 40-mile journey via taxi?
If 3 friends travel 58 miles by taxi and they decide to split the fair between them, how much will they each be paying?
If buses charge a fixed rate of $0.17 per mile, after how many miles will a taxi ride work out to be cheaper than a bus ride?

If a taxi driver drives a total of 60 miles in an hour, what is the highest possible amount of money that he can earn for that hour (given that each ride has to be at least 5 miles and he can conduct multiple rides in that hour)?

stems.text: The following graph compares the fuel consumption of a model of car (and its various years of models) with its fuel consumption. A car can be run on petrol, diesel or LPG/ CNG.

questions.text: How much more diesel would an individual driving a model from before 1990 use than an individual driving a model from after 2001 when travelling 565km?
How much farther could an individual (driving a 2005 model car) travel if he used 43L of petrol as opposed to 43L of LPG/ CNG?
1 mile = 1.6 km. If a woman drives a 1997 model car at an average speed of 38 miles/hour for 212 minutes, how much petrol will she use?

The price of diesel is 27% greater than the price of petrol (which is $1.25 per litre). How much farther can an individual travel (in a 2001 model car) with $80 worth of petrol than $80 worth of diesel?

stems.text: The following table compares the number of units of desks sold and shipped from a warehouse to furniture stores across the UK. The transportation of desks has an associated fixed cost of $10,000 and variable costs depending on the number of units purchased.

questions.text: What is the average cost per desk (incorporating the fixed costs into calculations) for 150 desks (in pounds)?
What percentage higher is the average cost per desk (incorporating the fixed costs into calculations) when 100 desks are sold as opposed to 250?
If the above model holds true for sales greater than 250 units, what is the minimum number of desks that need to be purchased such that the average cost per desk is below 125 pounds?
questions.explanation: 10,000 + 100x = 125x; x = 400; Below 125 pounds however; hence, 401 would be the answer

questions.text: One US dollar is equal to 0.83 pounds. A store in the UK buys 50 units of desks from the warehouse. The store then sells a desk to an American customer for 445 US dollars. Considering the average cost of each desk, what percentage profit was made on this sale by the store?

stems.text: Chris is running laps of his oval at school. The circumference of his school’s oval is 0.4 miles. The following table illustrates Chris’ cumulative distance run at various times since he began running. 1 mile = 1.6 km

questions.text: What was Chris’ average speed for his 30-minute run (in km/h)?
For which 5-minute time interval was Chris’ speed (in km/h) the fastest?
options: Can’t tell (as first 5-minute interval isn’t given)
questions.explanation: Most distance travelled (0.8 miles) between minutes 15 and 20

questions.text: Supposing that Chris travels at the same, average, speed for each 5-minute interval but alters his speed every 5 minutes, how many minutes did it take for Chris to run 4 laps of the school oval?

Jerome is also running laps at the same time as Chris but is a slower runner. They both start at the same point on the school oval’s circumference and start running at the same time. However, it takes only 20 minutes for Chris to overlap Jerome. Jerome travels at a constant speed for his entire run. In order to match the distance run by Chris in 30 minutes, how many more minutes does Jerome have to run for than Chris?

stems.text: The following table depicts the tax rate on the taxable income of individual Australians per year. Individuals keep whatever is left after tax has been deducted from taxable income.

questions.text: If an individual earns $163,476 in taxable income for a year, how much of that are they able to keep?
What is the average tax rate (in cents per dollar) for an individual who earns $49923 in taxable income for a year?
For an individual to have an average tax rate of less than 36 cents per dollar, what is the most that they can earn (in taxable income) per quarter/ 3 months (on average)?

If the conversion rate for American dollars to Australian dollars is 1.66. How much taxable income can an individual transfer from America (per year), at most, without having to pay an average tax rate of greater than 20c per $1 (give your answer in American dollars)?

stems.text: Initially, a large fish tank was filled with X gallons of water. Due to a leak in the fish tank, the volume of water in the fish tank gradually decreased at a constant rate. The following table illustrates the volume of water remaining in the fish tank since it was filled.

questions.text: What is the value of X?
After 17 hours, how much water will be remaining in the pool (in gallons)?
Given that the rate of water loss is constant, how long (total) will it take for the fish tank to completely empty?

In order to counter this loss of water, at the 10-hour mark a hose is used to pump water into the fish tank. Water continues to leak at the same rate; however, the house pumps water at a rate of 5 gallons per hour. After how long, since the house was turned on, would the fish tank start to overflow (in minutes)?

stems.text: At a tech company, employees are paid on an hourly basis depending on their employee classification level and the days/ hours they work. Employees’ lunch break is from 1 to 2 O’clock and if they work from 1 to 2, they will be paid extra (delayed meal break).

questions.text: What percentage more does a level 7 employee get paid per hour on a public holiday than a level 3A employee on a weekday (disregarding the potential for a delayed meal break)?
What percentage increase in hourly rate does a delayed meal break result in for a level 5 employee on Sunday?
How much longer will a level 4A employee have to work to generate $2000 than a level 6 employee (given both work only on weekends with normal meal breaks from 1 to 2)?

8 level 3 employees take 4 hours (collectively) to solve an issue at a tech company. Individually, a level 3 employee can solve the issue in 32 hours. How much would the company have to pay 16 level 3 employees to solve the issue (in total) - on a Thursday with normal meal breaks?

stems.text: A traffic light turns from red to green and a car accelerates from rest. The speed of the car in metres per second for the four seconds after the light turned green is illustrated on the graph below.

questions.text: What was the maximum speed (in km/h) reached by the car in the four seconds after the light turned green?
Acceleration is defined as the change in speed per unit of time. What is the average acceleration of the car for the first 2 seconds (in m/s/s)?

After reaching the speed, indicated on the graph, after 4 seconds, the car steadily accelerates – increasing its speed by 10% every second until it reaches the speed limit of 50km/h. How many seconds (from when the lights first turned green) does it take the car to reach 50km/h?

The car travels at an average speed of 45km/h for 10 minutes between the two traffic lights. A motorbike, having started at the same traffic light at the same time as the car, travels at an average speed of 48km/h between the two traffic lights. How much earlier did the motorbike arrive at the second set of traffic lights than the car?

stems.text: George went on a trip from Melbourne to Sydney, making stops along the way for breaks. The distance between Sydney and Melbourne is 350km.

questions.text: What was George’s average speed from Melbourne until his first break?
What was George’s average speed in the first two and a half hours of his journey?
If George travelled at a speed of 30km/h during his detour, how much longer did he spend travelling than if he did not take the detour?
What would have been George’s average speed over the whole journey if he had not taken his break or detoured?

stems.text: An experiment was conducted 6 times to see how far a ball went after being thrown from a slingshot, also measuring the time it took for the ball to touch the ground (assuming the ball stopped when it touched the ground) after being launched from the slingshot.

questions.text: How fast was the ball travelling in the air during the second trial (to 2 decimal places)?
How much faster was the ball in the 5th trial travelling in the air compared to the ball in the 6th trial (to 2 decimal places)?
If the ball in the third trial was travelling in the air at a speed of 33.33 inches/sec, how long did it take for the ball to touch the ground (to 2 decimal places)?
If 1 inch = 3 cm, how fast was the ball in the fourth trial travelling in cm/sec, to the nearest cm?

stems.text: The following table shows the results of an experiment where 6 boys blew a spitball in the classroom to see how far the spitball went and they recorded the time it took to hit the classroom wall. All the boys’ spitballs hit the wall.

questions.text: How fast was the first boy’s spitball travelling, to the nearest millimeter?
If the second boy’s spitball was travelling at a speed of 400cm/sec, how much further did his spitball go compared to the fourth boy’s?
If the average speed of the spitballs of boys 3-6 was 122.32cm/sec, how much time did it take for the 5th boy’s spitball to hit the classroom wall, to 2 decimal places?
Whose spitball travelled the slowest out of all the 6 boys (excluding boy 2 and 5)?
questions.explanation: Boy 1 was the only boy whose spitball travelled less than 100cm/sec

stems.text: There are only 4 trains in Canada, Train 693, 691, 690 and 692. Below are some of the stops as well as the arrival and departure times of those trains from those stops, as well as the days on which the train does not stop at that particular place. All the stops follow in sequential order on the table (ie. the first stop for Train 693 on Monday is Winnipeg, then The Pas… etc, the last being Churchill). If a train does not stop at a place on a particular day, it starts/stops/continues its journey from the next stop.  A route consists of all the stops the train needs to stop at for that day. Unless otherwise specified, trains depart 10 minutes after arrival. The times are in 24-hour time.

questions.text: On Tuesdays, how long does it take for Train 690 to complete its route?
If the distance by rail from Churchill to Gillam is 600km, how fast is Train 692 going on its route on Wednesday?
If John wants to get from Thompson to Winnipeg in the shortest amount of time possible on Tuesday, which train should he take?
questions.explanation: Takes only 5 hrs 15 minutes via train 692 (11:30 to 16:45)

questions.text: If Train 693 travels at a constant speed of 70km/h on its route, how far does it travel on one route (to the nearest km)?
questions.explanation: Time taken for the full route = 39 hours; 39 * 70 = 2730

stems.text: Everyday James goes to school, which is 30km away from his house. On Tuesdays and Wednesdays, he walks to school and runs home from school, but every other day of the week from Monday to Friday he rides his bike to school and back. On weekends he likes to go to his friend Bobby’s house, which is 20km away from his house and 15km away from the school.

questions.text: If he rides his bike at a speed of 15km/h, how long would it take him to go from home to school and back on Thursday?
If he walks at a pace of 8km/h and runs at a speed 1.5 times faster, how long would it take him to get home from school on Wednesday?

James decides it’s taking him too long to get to school by bike, riding at a speed of 20km/h. He decides to carpool with Bobby, but that means he needs to get to Bobby’s house before they leave and ride home from Bobby’s house on the way back. Bobby’s mum drives at 40km/h How much times would James save by doing this on Monday?
If he spends 15 hours a week riding his bike to school, how fast does he ride (assuming he travels at the same speed consistently the whole week)?
